results.title: Amazon Pushes Facial Recognition to Police. Critics See Surveillance Risk.
results.abstract: More than two dozen civil rights organizations asked the tech giant to stop selling its image recognition system to law enforcement agencies.

multimedia.caption: Amazon’s campus in downtown Seattle. The American Civil Liberties Union and other civil rights groups are asking the company to stop selling its image-recognition system, Rekognition, to law enforcement authorities.

results.title: Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg Gets an Earful From the E.U.
results.abstract: The chief executive had initially resisted meeting with European authorities, who have emerged as the world’s most assertive watchdog of the technology industry.
results.byline: By ADAM SATARIANO and MILAN SCHREUER

multimedia.caption: The Facebook chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, went to the European Parliament in Brussels on Tuesday to answer lawmakers’ questions over his social media company’s handling of user data.

results.title: Mark Zuckerberg to Apologize Again, This Time to European Parliament
results.abstract: Facebook’s chief executive is expected to strike a conciliatory tone about user data on Tuesday when he speaks to members of the European Parliament.

multimedia.caption: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, is expected to stick to what has become a well-used script when he appears before European lawmakers in Brussels.

results.title: Is Facebook Just a Platform? A Lawyer to the Stars Says No
results.abstract: Paul Tweed attracted star clients by suing publishers in Belfast, London and Dublin. He plans to hold the social media giants to the same standards.

multimedia.caption: “I say to Facebook, ‘What is the difference between you and a national newspaper being responsible for the letters they publish on their letters page? Why do you have to be treated differently?” said the lawyer Paul Tweed.
multimedia.copyright: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press

multimedia.caption: “I say to Facebook, ‘What is the difference between you and a national newspaper being responsible for the letters they publish on their letters page? Why do you have to be treated differently?” said the lawyer Paul Tweed.
multimedia.copyright: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press

results.title: Tesla Model 3 Goes Upscale, and Base-Price Buyers Must Wait
results.abstract: Elon Musk, the electric-car company’s chief, said Tesla would lose money and die if it began selling the cheapest version of its mass-market car too soon.

multimedia.caption: Tesla’s Model 3, between the larger Model S and Model X, in a San Diego showroom. So far the company has made only versions selling for $49,000 or more, but not the $35,000 base model.

results.title: G.E. Spins Off Railroad Business
results.abstract: G.E.’s unit that manufactures locomotives will be combined with the Wabtec Corporation, in the first move under John Flannery to shed an entire business.

multimedia.caption: General Electric diesel locomotives at a manufacturing plant in Fort Worth. The company is spinning off its railroad business in an $11 billion deal.

results.title: Former Uber Engineer’s Lawsuit Claims Sexual Harassment
results.abstract: As Uber works to remake its tarnished image, the company is still dealing with the fallout from its past misdeeds.

results.title: New Cancer Treatments Lie Hidden Under Mountains of Paperwork
results.abstract: Guideposts to powerful treatments may be buried in the nation’s medical records. But there is no easy way to gather those records or to get them into a usable format.

results.title: Finding Your Contacts in the New Gmail
results.abstract: Google’s recent revamp of its mail service has moved a few old features to new places, but you don’t have to look far.

multimedia.caption: In the updated version of Gmail for the desktop, you can get to your contacts from the Apps panel on the right side of the window, or by hovering the mouse cursor over a sender’s name until a contact card pops up.

results.title: Germany Acts to Tame Facebook, Learning From Its Own History of Hate
results.abstract: A country taps its past as it leads the way on one of the most pressing issues facing modern democracies: how to regulate the world’s biggest social network.

multimedia.caption: At a Facebook deletion center in Berlin, the agents, who work for a third-party firm, remove illegal hate speech from the social network.

results.title: Me and My Numb Thumb: A Tale of Tech, Texts and Tendons
results.abstract: Continually texting and emailing from her smartphone strained the tendons in this tech reporter’s phone thumb, which turns out to be an increasingly common condition.

results.abstract: Aaron Traywick envisioned a future in which self-taught scientists would cure diseases and bend the human body to their will.

results.title: Hundreds of Apps Can Empower Stalkers to Track Their Victims
results.abstract: Widely available services offer a range of spying abilities, including tracking people’s phones and harvesting their texts. As survivors seek help, the legal and technical hurdles are many.
des_facet: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

multimedia.caption: More than 200 apps and services offer would-be stalkers a variety of electronic capabilities, including basic location tracking, harvesting texts and secretly recording video.

results.title: Tech Hit This Small Town Hard. Now, Locals Hope It Will Fuel a Revival.
results.abstract: Holywell, a town in Wales with dozens of local retailers, has struggled with the impacts of online shopping. It is applying technology to try and keep its shops open.

multimedia.caption: Holywell’s High Street is a shell of its former self, as e-commerce and bigger cities increasingly draw shoppers.

results.title: When Thousands Filled a Hilton Ballroom to Ponder the Future of Bitcoin
results.abstract: A gathering in New York this week for Consensus 2018, a blockchain-themed event, had all of the trappings of a modern business conference — a sign that the once-fringe world is increasingly going mainstream.

results.title: Turning Phone Videos Into GIFs
results.abstract: Several apps and services make it easy to turn that perfect video snippet into an animated GIF file that you can share by text message or email.

multimedia.caption: Apps like GIF Maker for Android are inexpensive and make it easy to convert a video clip to an animated GIF in just a few steps.

results.abstract: A weeklong blockchain conference in New York, changes at Uber, a “transparency report” from Facebook, and more.

results.title: Cleared of Spying for China, She Still Doesn’t Have Her Job Back
results.abstract: Three years ago, Sherry Chen, a hydrologist working for the National Weather Service, had charges against her dropped. A judge says she should be able to return to work.

multimedia.caption: An independent board ruled that the Commerce Department must reinstate Sherry Chen to her job at the National Weather Service, after a judge suggested that officials had buried exculpatory evidence.

results.abstract: The Silicon Valley digital payments company reached a deal for iZettle, which is Europe’s answer to the mobile payments company Square.

results.title: In Virtual Reality, How Much Body Do You Need?
results.abstract: It might be as little as a pair of hands and feet, researchers in Japan found after recording subjects who wore an Oculus Rift headset.

results.title: ‘Will You Be My Emergency Contact?’ Takes On a Whole New Meaning
results.abstract: Researchers mined medical records to build family trees they hope could help advance medical research, but the privacy implications worry some bioethicists.

results.title: Thanks, Internet: Estonian Town Gets Cannabis Leaf as Its Emblem
results.abstract: Online voters overwhelmingly favored putting the marijuana plant on the flag of Kanepi, a municipality that has a tradition of growing hemp.

multimedia.caption: The cannabis leaf design for the flag and emblem of Kanepi, Estonia. A town official defended the decision as a “very democratic” process, even though the number of online voters in favor of it — about 12,000 — easily surpassed the municipality’s population of 5,000.

results.title: China, Signaling Thaw With U.S. Over Trade, Approves Toshiba Microchip Deal
results.abstract: Chinese antitrust officials allowed the Japanese company to sell a majority stake in its chip unit to an American-led group, a prelude to an easing of tensions between Washington and Beijing.
results.byline: By CARLOS TEJADA and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

multimedia.caption: Toshiba once symbolized Japan's technological might, but it has more recently been scrambling to survive.

results.title: New Ways to Delete Old Files
results.abstract: Last month’s update to Windows 10 added new tools for automatically and manually clearing clutter from your hard drive.

multimedia.caption: In the Storage Sense settings, you can decide how often you want Windows to self clean, or you can use the "Free up space now" option to instantly dig up and delete superfluous files.

results.title: Why Am I Crying All the Time?
results.abstract: Homecoming videos, GoFundMe campaigns, “This Is Us” tweets — the internet wants not just your eyeballs, but your tears.

results.title: Senate Democrats Win Vote on Net Neutrality, a Centerpiece of 2018 Strategy
results.abstract: The rare victory for Democrats is sure to be short-lived in Congress, but they plan to use the issue to get young voters engaged in midterm elections.

results.title: Google’s File on Me Was Huge. Here’s Why It Wasn’t as Creepy as My Facebook Data.
results.abstract: Google collects far more information about us than Facebook. But the Google data that our tech columnist downloaded on himself contained fewer surprises and was more easily deleted.

results.title: The Entire Economy Is MoviePass Now. Enjoy It While You Can.
results.abstract: Inspired by Silicon Valley’s hyper-growth, companies elsewhere are burning cash in hopes of being the next big thing.

results.title: Killing Spurs Didi, China’s Ride-Hailing Giant, to Revamp Its Service
results.abstract: Didi Chuxing said it would overhaul its app, as well as safety and security practices, after the death of a passenger focused attention on the company.
results.byline: By ELSIE CHEN and MENGXUE OU

multimedia.caption: The Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing says it has 450 million users. It has expanded at a breakneck pace within China and around the world.

results.title: How to Record Your iPhone Screen
results.abstract: In iOS 11, you can make a video of what’s happening directly on your phone at the moment — without having to install an extra app.

results.title: New Privacy Rules Could Make This Woman One of Tech’s Most Important Regulators
results.abstract: With Europe’s sweeping new data privacy law, Ireland is in the middle of a standoff between regulators and tech companies.

results.title: Assassin’s Creed Has a New Mission: Working in the Classroom
results.abstract: The long-running historical video game franchise has debuted an educational mode for its latest release, set in Ptolemaic Egypt.
